The AP-LS Executive Committee voted unanimously to approve the revisions and submit them to the AP-LS membership for ratification.  Per the existing By-Laws language in Article VI, Section 1: “Ratification of the proposed amendment requires a two-thirds majority of those of the membership voting, or by a two-thirds vote of those members attending any annual meeting.” The AP-LS Executive Committee is therefore asking AP-LS members to ratify the By-Laws revisions.  Please review this document in advance of the voting to review a summary of the key changes as well the line-by-line specific proposed changes.  The voting link will be mailed to all members eligible to vote soon.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                AP-LS 2017 CONFERENCE: SEATTLE  This year's conference will be held at The Westin Hotel in Seattle, Washington from March 16-18, 2017, with optional pre-conference workshops on March 15.          Update From the Conference Co-Chairs, Kathleen Kemp and Derek Hess  We are excited to provide these highlights for the upcoming AP-LS 2017 Conference. The program schedule will be completed in the coming weeks. For more information and to register for the conference, click here.  Continued Source for Great CE & CLE creditsAP-LS will continue to offer CEs for this year’s conference through CONCEPT. We hope CLEs will also be available. Pre-Conference Workshops – Wed, March 15thPlease see this flyer for more details about the fantastic full and half-day workshops at this year’s conference.A Conversation with Amanda KnoxThe prosecution of Amanda Knox for the murder of her British roommate in Italy captured worldwide attention from when she was arrested in 2007 to when she was exonerated in 2015. Saul Kassin, PhD will discuss the psychological factors that tainted the investigation and prosecution. Amanda Knox will reflect on her experience and share the life she now lives. Cutting Edge PlenariesThursday, March 16th – Charles H. Ramsey, Police CommissionerCharles H. Ramsey is a former Chief of the Metropolitan Police Department (D.C.), Commissioner for Philadelphia Police Department, and co-chair of President Obama’s Taskforce on 21st Century Policing. Commissioner Ramsey will address various challenges and opportunities associated with community policing. Friday, March 17th – Adam Foss, J.D., Co-founder and President of Prosecutor ImpactAdam Foss is a former Assistant District Attorney in the Juvenile Division of the Suffolk County District Attorney’s Office in Boston, MA, and a fierce advocate for juvenile justice reform and the importance of the role of the prosecutor in reforming the justice system. His vision can be previewed in his February 2016 Ted Talk, A Prosecutor’s Vision for a Better Justice System.Saturday, March 18th – Making a Murderer: The Case of Brendan DasseyIn relation to the Netflix documentary series, Making a Murderer, persons integral to the defense and ultimate release of Steven Avery’s nephew, Brendan Dassey, will discuss why Dassey was a vulnerable suspect; the interrogation tactics that were used to elicit and contaminate his confession; and the implications more generally for juvenile justice, police interrogations, and other matters of policy and practice. This is a unique opportunity to expand upon a series that captivated millions, and illustrates salient to false confessions today.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               COMMITTEE NEWS & UPDATESEach year AP-LS Committees sponsor sessions related to their area of focus. Here is a preview of the expert presenters and panelists presenting throughout the conference. Corrections – The Future of Corrections ReformDr. Nneka Jones-Tapia is the Executive Director of the largest psychiatric treatment facility in the USA – Chicago’s Cook County Jail. She will address the future of correctional reform and avenues for being a change agent within its complex system.Early Career Professionals & Social Media – Professional Social Media UseWe will introduce how social media platforms can be used to help professionals build relationships, portfolios, and awareness. We will discuss the pros and cons of the platforms available and give tips on how to use social media time wisely to reach professional objectives. Legal Scholars – Psychological Research in the Criminal Justice SystemThis session will be led by law professors interested in psychological research applied to the criminal justice system. We will address dangerousness in commitment and sentencing; expert testimony in child sex abuse prosecutions; mindfulness training for lawyers; and mental disability re: consent in alleged rape cases.Professional Development of Women / ECP / TTC – Becoming a Successful NegotiatorCatharine Morrison, J.D., an expert in negotiation, conflict management, and managing difficult conversations, will address key concepts for negotiation. The session will include simulations and Q&A. Registration is strongly encouraged (but not required) to access to the preparatory e-modules. Contact Gina Vincent by March 6th to access to the modules.Students – Conducting Research to Address Real-World ProblemsA panel of legal practitioners will discuss how they utilize social science research in their work, and identify ways in which research could be applied more effectively in legal contexts and settings. Teaching, Training, and Careers – Social Justice Teaching & Training TechniquesThis session will foster critical thought regarding social justice pedagogy, and provide specific strategies to address the cultural, socio-political, and economic realities of society, including utilizing the emotional impact of film. INTERESTED IN SERVING ON AN AP-LS COMMITTEE?The Executive Committee invites self-nominations for committee members and chairs. We welcome participation among all members and wish to represent in our governance the full diversity of our membership. Terms are normally three years. Full committee terms of reference (descriptions of committees) are here.  If you're interested in serving on one of these committees, please fill out this form.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              Welcome to the April 2017 American Psychology-Law Society      (AP-LS) E-Newsletter.Our monthly E-News provides information about activities, upcoming events, and resources to connect the psychology-law community.AP-LS aspires to excel as a valuable, effective, and influential organization advancing the science of psychology-law and the translation of psychology-law knowledge into practice and policy.  Our most recent full PDF Newsletter (Winter 2017) is available here. We plan to replace the PDF Newsletter with the e-newsletters.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           CALL FOR E-NEWS EDITOR  AP-LS has had a quarterly PDF newsletter for many years. However, as part of the organization's plan to become more nimble and modern, we are phasing out the old quarterly PDF newsletter and replacing it with these monthly e-news mailings.  We will continue to have the same kinds of content as the PDF newsletter, but will now deliver the content across 12 months rather than just 4 times per year.    The time has come for a new editor to be appointed to the post.  Matthew Huss's term as the PDF newsletter editor is coming to a close, and AP-LS would like to appoint the new editor to take over the e-news and help transition us from the PDF format into this newer e-news format.Are you interested in serving in this new e-news editor role?  If so, please send an email with your statement of interest and your CV to Jennifer Woolard.  AP-LS COMMITTEE SERVICE OPPORTUNITIESA Note for Committee Chairs and Interested MembersWe launched a google form about two months ago to have people indicate their interest in serving on various AP-LS committees, and the form was announced at the conference too. We have hundreds of people interested in serving on committees, which is great news!  The committee chairs will begin going through the data soon and contacting people who indicated interest in their committees.We are asking all committee chairs and all interested people serving in committees to use this form for the new member application process for the sake of consistency, transparency, and fairness.Full committee terms of reference (descriptions of committees) are here. Committee chairs will use the responses to the form to then contact interested applicants directly with a request for more information. Service terms are normally three years, with initial appointments in August.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW: ADVANCES IN PSYCHOLOGY AND LAW      Part of AP-LS President David DeMatteo's presidential initiative is to send out quarterly updates regarding new cases, laws, etc. that are of interest to the psychology-law community. These updates will be published in the e-news, and the first installment is ready this month.      Jan - Mar 2017 Update    This is the first installment of a quarterly review and summary of the valuable advancements in the psychological and legal fields. Our goal is to present this information in a comprehensive, but an easily digestible format. Each update will include summaries of relevant and current research findings and legal developments with links to further information.  Sometimes staying on top of all the news, research and legal updates relevant to the field can be a daunting task. Our hope with this quarterly update is to save you some time and keep you informed!     In the Courtroom  Jury Decision-MakingWorried about evidence suggesting race bias in juries? On March 6, 2017, the Supreme Court ruled that courts must make an exception to the rule that jury deliberations remain secret if they are impacted by racial or ethnic bias. See Pena-Rodriguez v. Colorado. For those who do conduct jury simulation research, this new study may help alleviate concerns about using undergraduate student samples to represent mock juries.Using Race as a Risk Factor: Racial Bias in the CourtroomThe Supreme Court recently held that a Texas death row inmate’s sentencing was unfairly biased by blatantly racist expert testimony. In short, his own attorney’s expert testified that the defendant is more likely to commit violent acts because he is black. See Buck v. Davis.Juvenile Sentencing: What Does Society Think?As a reminder, SCOTUS recently held that mandatory life in prison without parole (LWOP)  for juvenile offenders is unconstitutional (because it violates the 8th Amendment prohibition of “cruel and unusual punishment”).  But what about non-mandatory LWOP sentencing? A recent study examined the public’s sentiment regarding juvenile LWOP and, among other findings, found that only 31% of participants agree with juvenile LWOP as a general policy.Intellectual Disability and the Death PenaltyOn March 28, 2017 the Supreme Court continued its trend toward limiting capital punishment for those with intellectual disability (continued in next column).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               WHAT YOU SHOULD KNOW (CONTINUED)(Continued from previous column). The Court rejected Texas’s standards for deciding whether an individual’s intellectual disability would preclude him from receiving the death penalty. In writing for the majority, Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg reasoned that Texas’s approach was not consistent with current medical standards, placed too much weight on I.Q. scores, and considered factors rooted in stereotypes.  See Moore v. Texas. In the Community     Improving the Process for Prisoner ReentryReentry programming for previously incarcerated offenders seems like a great idea, but where is the research supporting it? Recent research has shown that individuals feel they may not be receiving the services they need. So what’s the answer? Better integrate offender-perceived needs with needs highlighted in actuarial assessments.This bill filed in Kentucky, if passed, may be a good model for improving success in reentry. The bill aims to provide workforce training during incarceration, ease restrictions that prevent released offenders from getting jobs, and provide a reentry drug supervision pilot program.Improving Citizen-Law Enforcement Relations: Police AccountabilityThis global multi-site randomized clinical trial examined the use of body-worn cameras on police and whether it reduced citizen’s complaints. Studies like this are increasingly more important as tensions have increased among officers and the populations they serve.Mental Health Care & the Trump AdministrationAs many are aware, the Trump administration has begun to withdraw federal protections for transgender individuals. This will likely have a large impact on the transgender community, and an even larger impact for incarcerated transgender individuals. As institutional barriers are resurrected, it might be helpful for practicing clinicians to review these guidelines when working with transgender clients. As the status of the Affordable Care Act remains in question, see this article for the perspective of some concerned psychologists.  Final ThoughtsAnd Lastly, on a positive note…For information on a promising program, check out NPR’s inspiring Hidden Brain podcast on a CBT program in Chicago designed to reduce violence and increase high school graduate rates among teenage boys.Until June!If you have questions, or see or read something you would like to see included in future updates, please contact us! OPINION: A SPOT ON A COWContent Contributor: Antoinette Kavanaugh, Ph.D., ABPPAt a recent family reunion in North Carolina, I was having breakfast with my aunt and her family. At one point, her kids shared a story about while growing up, they would go to events like the state fair and be one of the few families of color present. They would look at each other, smile, and say “Spot on a cow.” This is how they acknowledged that they were some of the few people of color at an event or outing. In this brief essay I will explain how being a spot on a cow led to my becoming a forensic psychologist and how it continues to shape the way I conceptualize and conduct forensic interviews.To read the column, please click here.RESEARCH BRIEFSTake a look at the latest research briefs for short summaries of the latest articles relevant to psychology-law. To read the research briefs, please click here.NEWSLETTER ARCHIVES  Archives of the  newsletter are available at http://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/Newsletter. Newsletter. Our monthly Newsletter provides information about activities, upcoming events, and resources to connect the psychology-law community. AP-LS aspires to excel as a valuable, effective, and                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 KEEP AP-LS’ VOICE HEARD AT APA If you are a member of the American Psychological Association (APA), you should have received your 2019 APA Ballot Election via e-mail on November 1. It is important that you promptly respond to this email to help keep AP-LS's voice heard within APA.Your vote will determine how many voting members AP-LS gets on APA's governing body, the Council of Representatives. Right now, AP-LS has two representatives. Depending on the number of votes that AP-LS gets during this ballot process, AP-LS could gain or lose a representative. Each APA member is given 10 votes. Please give all 10 of your votes to Division 41/AP-LS. This ballot also includes a proposed change to the APA bylaws to allow some graduate student members the right to vote in some APA elections, as further explained on the ballot. In August, the APA Council of Representatives (including the two AP-LS representatives) voted in favor (73.4%) of the item, and the APA Board of Directors recommended approval. If you have any questions, please contact Jason Cantone, at jasoncantone@gmail.com. If you are an APA member and did not receive the ballot email, please contact Garnett Coad, at gcoad@apa.org. UNDERSTANDING THE NEEDS OF AP-LS EARLY CAREER PROFESSIONALSIn late 2018, 119 AP-LS early career professionals (ECPs) completed a detailed survey regarding their graduate training, professional development, current career path, and recommendations for how AP-LS can meet the needs of ECPs. This survey provided a wealth of information. Some findings include: -  Diversity. Respondents overwhelmingly self-identified as White (81%) and female (83%) and noted a need for more diversity awareness and recruitment, as well as a desire for more training in socio-cultural issues in law and psychology, and harassment and discrimination claims. - Debt. Respondents’ average student debt load at the time of graduation was a little over $100,000, with about $89,000 attributable solely to graduate training. Respondents who received a PsyD reported the highest debt load. - Meeting ECP Needs.  Only 5% of respondents said that AP-LS addressed their needs extremely well, with the most saying moderately well. Respondents recommended that AP-LS provide further opportunities regarding peer networking, professional networking, and how to establish collaborations outside of academia. - Policy and Applied Areas. Respondents reported satisfaction with many aspects of their graduate training, but many expressed disappointment with a lack of guidance on going into the non-academic job market, and a need for more training in policy areas and better experiential learning opportunities. This was especially likely for social science respondents. The full report is available here. Questions can be directed to Jason Cantone, at jasoncantone@gmail.com. ON THE JOB OR POSTDOC MARKET? AP-LS JOB POSTINGSCheck out AP-LS's Job Postings Page for up-to-date information on available psychology-law positions here.Note that new positions are available.NEWSLETTER ARCHIVESArchives of the  newsletter are available at http://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/Newsletter.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 2019 SALEEM SHAH AWARD: CALL FOR NOMINATIONSThe Saleem Shah Award is an annual award co-sponsored by the American Academy of Forensic Psychology (AAFP) and the American Psychology-Law Society (AP-LS), recognizing early career excellence and contributions to the field of psychology and law.  The focus of a nominee's contributions may be in any area of forensic psychology practice, research, or public policy. The recipient must have received the doctoral degree (or law degree, whichever comes later, if both have been earned) within the last 6 years (Year 2013 or later, inclusive of 2013). The award includes $2,000, as well as the opportunity to give the Saleem Shah Address at the next meeting of the American Psychology-Law Society.  Nominations must include (1) a letter detailing the nominee’s contributions to psychology and law and (2) a copy of the nominee’s vita.  Self-nominations will not be considered.  Nominations are due by midnight EST on November 30, 2019.Nominations should be sent electronically, in PDF or Word format, to Bob Stinson, Psy.D., J.D., LICDC-CS, ABPP, President-Elect of AAFP: Stinson@StinsonAndAssociates.com.DISSERTATION AWARDSThe American Psychology-Law Society confers Dissertation Awards for scientific research and scholarship relevant to the promotion of the interdisciplinary study of psychology and law. Students who complete dissertations involving basic or applied research in psychology and law in 2019 are encouraged to apply for these awards. First, second, and third-place awards will be conferred; winners will be invited to present their research at the annual AP-LS conference and receive a cash award.Submissions are due by 12/31/19.For application details, please click here, or, for more information, please contact Jacqueline Evans, the chair of the Dissertation Awards Committee, at jacevans@fiu.edu. CALL FOR PAPERSThe ComplianceNet 2020 conference will take place on June 29–30, 2020, and will be hosted by the University College London (UCL) School of Public Policy/Department of Political Science and the UCL Global Governance Institute. We are currently accepting panel or paper submissions, with a submission deadline of January 24, 2020.  If you are unfamiliar with the organization, ComplianceNet seeks to bring together scholars from a range of different disciplines to study the interaction between rules and human behaviour, broadly defined. The first two meetings have been highly successful, bringing together academics from business, criminology, economics, law, political science, psychology and sociology, among other fields. See the ComplianceNet website here for more details about its structure and goals. Prospective participants may submit either panel proposals (containing three to five thematically-linked papers) or individual paper proposals (which will be assigned to thematic panels after the submission deadline). The submission deadline is January 24, 2020.AP-LS CONTACTSEmail addresses for all current EC members and Committee Chairs can be found here.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        LAW AND HUMAN BEHAVIOR UPDATEBradley D. McAuliff, JD, PhD (bradley.mcauliff@csun.edu)California State University, NorthridgeThe Editorial Team recently received two important journal updates that we would like to share with Division 41.This summer, Clarivate Analytics’ Social Science Citation Index released LHB’s impact factor for 2018. Measuring the average number of times articles from the journal published in 2016 and 2017 were cited in 2018, the impact factor decreased slightly from 2.867 in 2017 to 2.780 in 2018. The journal’s 5-year impact factor, measuring the average number of times articles from the journal published between 2013 and 2017 were cited in 2018, rose from to 3.245 to 3.372.LHB’s ranking in the law category was 11 out of 148 and the journal was outranked by only one other psychology title, European Journal of Psychology Applied to Legal Context, which is an open access journal. In the social psychology category, LHB ranked 15 out of 63.APA Journals also released its annual publishing report for LHB. The rate of submissions to the journal in 2018 increased 3% compared to 2017 and the rate is about 12% higher so far this year. The rejection rate decreased slightly from 85% last year to 81% in 2018. Editorial lag, or time between submission and first decision, also decreased from 6 weeks in 2017 to 4 weeks last year. Production lag, or time between acceptance and publication in an issue, was about 6 weeks for articles posted online and less than 3 months for articles included in issues.The impact of LHB--combined with the steady submission rate, a short editorial and publication lag, and a rejection rate that hovers around 80%--suggests the journal remains very healthy. That said, we continue to need your best work! This is especially the case for clinical submissions, which are underrepresented and constitute roughly 20% of all submissions to the journal. Please consider submitting now and do not hesitate to contact me, or any of the Associate Editors (David DeMatteo, Amanda Zelechoski, Jennifer Hunt, Lora Levett, and Kyle Scherr) if you have any questions or we can help in any way.CALL FOR SYLLABIThe TTC Committee is continuing its efforts to collect syllabi for courses in Psychology and Law or closely related topics. There are already a number of syllabi that have been collected over the years on the AP-LS website. However, we would like to routinely post new syllabi. We would appreciate your assistance in providing us with a copy of your syllabi.If you have not already provided one, please do so in the following way: Send a copy of your syllabi to Jonathan Golding (golding@uky.edu). Soft copies may be submitted as e-mail attachments (Word Perfect, Word, or ASCII files are preferred).AP-LS BOOK AWARD COMMITTEE INVITES NOMINATIONSThe AP-LS Book Award Committee is inviting nominations to recognize outstanding scholarship in psychology and law edited books published in 2017 and 2018. The deadline for nomination is November 8, 2019. Nominations (including self-nominations) and e-versions of the book should be sent to the Chair of the Committee: Marie Comiskey, BA LLB LLM SJD, marie.comiskey@utoronto.ca. The award will be presented at the upcoming AP-LS Conference in New Orleans in March 2020. The award rotates annually between edited and authored books. OPINION: WHY FORENSIC PSYCHOLOGY CORE COMPETENCIES ARE IMPORTANTContent Contributors: Ayanna Payne, M.A. & Alvin Thomas, Ph.D.For over 30 years forensic psychology has been established as a distinct specialty within the field of psychology. Though applying psychological research to the legal system goes back as far as 1885, it was officially recognized by the American Psychological Association in 2001 and has since experienced rapid growth.  As the field of forensic psychology continues to advance, it is imperative training and educational curricula adequately prepares future practitioners and researchers alike.To read this column, please click here.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 LEGAL UPDATE: CONTINUING EDUCATION TO BETTER ENHANCE THE ATTORNEY/CLINICIAN RELATIONSHIPContent Contributors: Michael L. Perlin, Esq. & Heather Ellis CucoloThe two of us have taught together, written together, consulted and presented together for years. Mostly, we have done this with lawyers, law students, psychologists and psychology students. For 14 years, one of us (MLP) ran an online mental disability law program at New York Law School (NYLS), and for the last five, HEC has run it. Through this program, we have offered courses at NYLS and at other law schools and graduate schools (including a school of professional psychology) throughout the US and in multiple foreign nations. We also, for eight years, ran a masters’ program in mental disability law studies, and psychologists regularly made up a majority of students in that program. And we created a joint program with John Jay so that students could receive a J.D. from NYLS and an M.A. in forensic psychology from Jay.To read this column, please click here. PSYCHOLOGY AND LAW: BRINGING THE CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM TO LIFE INSIDE THE CLASSROOMContent Contributor: Sara Appleby, Ph.D.When a last minute cancellation put her prison-based course back in the traditional classroom, Dr. Appleby had to quickly find ways to bring the complex dynamics and real voices of the criminal justice system to life for her students.  This month, she shares diverse resources and methods for use inside the classroom.To read this column, please click here.CALL FOR PAPERS: BEHAVIORAL SCIENCES AND THE LAW – SPECIAL ISSUE ON POLICINGBehavioral Sciences & the Law announces a forthcoming special issue on Policing, to be edited by Christopher Slobogin, J.D., LL.M., a senior editor for the journal. Manuscripts that address the following issues are especially welcome: (1) research on the “benefits” and “costs” of various policing techniques, measured in procedural justice or other metrics; (2) research on how police should handle people with mental illness; (3) research on the psychological effects of surveillance by the police; (4) research on the psychological impact of policing on police officers.For more information, please click here. ON THE JOB OR POSTDOC MARKET? AP-LS JOB POSTINGSCheck out AP-LS's Job Postings Page for up-to-date information on available psychology-law positions here.Note that new positions are available.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               ANNUAL CONFERENCE MARCH 2020The AP-LS Annual Conference is March 5-7, 2020 at The Sheraton New Orleans Hotel 500 Canal Street New Orleans, LA. Please visit: http://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/APLS2020 for the latest information regarding the conference. In addition, if you have any thoughts or ideas regarding plenary speakers, please feel free to e-mail any of us. We are starting our pursuit of plenary speakers and would love any ideas or assistance members may be able to provide.Kento Yasuhara (APLS2020Yasuhara@gmail.com), Apryl Alexander (APLS2020Alexander@gmail.com), and Angelica Hagsand (APLS2020Hagsand@gmail.com). SPECIAL JOURNAL ISSUE ON JUVENILE JUSTICE RESEARCHDescribed by:  Thomas Grisso, Erika Fountain, Amanda NeMoyer & Laura ThorntonThe June 2019 e issue of the APA journal Translational Issues in Psychological Science is a special issue  titled “Psychological Science and Juvenile Justice.”  Its  editorial classifies the various phases or steps in the research process of translating basic behavioral science to create, implement and evaluate methods for use in juvenile justice. The eight peer-reviewed  articles in the special issue demonstrate various levels of translational research. To read this column, click here.CAREER CORNERThe Career Corner is intended to highlight the individuals who work at the intersection of law and psychology, where they come from, how they got there and how their experiences influence their research, teaching, and/or practice. This edition of Career Corner profiles Virginia Barber-Rioja, Ph.D., the Clinical Director of Mental Health at Correctional Health Services/NYC Health + Hospitals and Clinical Professor of Psychiatry at New York University School of Medicine.To read this column, please click here.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      AP-LS VOICES HEARD IN APACongratulations to Dr. Erika Fountain on her selection as a member of the new APA Advisory Group for Applied Psychology. The advisory group, which will be led by APA's Office of Applied Psychology, will have two main charges: 1) to make recommendations about how applied psychology can be better represented in APA; and 2) serve as a source of input and feedback regarding applied psychology issues and priorities. We are excited to see AP-LS part of this important advisory group.Jason Cantone was selected for the new APA Work Group on Accommodating Young Families. The work group is tasked with examining how APA could better support young families attending governance meetings and the annual convention (e.g., child care grants, on-site child care, nursing resources, family-friendly resources). During the first meeting, AP-LS was commended for its child care grants to assist families attending the annual AP-LS conference. If you're interested in serving on an APA group, APA is currently looking for new members for its Continuing Education Committee (applications due August 12), Committee on Early Career Psychologists (due August 28), Committee on Disability Issues in Psychology (due August 30), and APA Fellows Committee (due September 10). PRODUCTIVITY AND IMPACT: DOING MORE WITH LESSThe Early Career Professionals and Professional Development of Women Committees organized a special session for the 2019, APLS Conference in Portland, OR: Productivity and Impact: Doing More with Less.  Dr. Tess Neal (See bio below) provided one of the presentations, which we would like to share with you.  Below, please find a link to her talk on productivity and impact.  Please also take advantage of the handy tip sheet: Enjoy Life, Work Strategically. Link to PDF: Tess Neal’s Enjoy Life, Work StrategicallyLink to Video: https://soapbox.wistia.com/videos/MPQdJlvrU9Tess Neal is an assistant professor of psychology in ASU's New College of Interdisciplinary Arts and Sciences and is a founding faculty member of ASU's Law and Behavioral Science group. She is both a scientist and a licensed psychologist, and directs the Clinical and Legal Judgment Lab at ASU.  Her research is funded by multiple grants from the National Science Foundation, and she has published one edited book and three dozen peer-reviewed publications in such journals as American Psychologist; PLOS ONE; Psychology, Public Policy, and Law; and Criminal Justice and Behavior. She is currently leading a project commissioned by the Association for Psychological Science for the high-impact journal Psychological Science in the Public Interest.  She is the recipient of the 2016 Saleem Shah Award for Early Career Excellence in Psychology and Law, co-awarded by the American Psychology-Law Society and the American Academy of Forensic Psychology. She was named a 2016 "Rising Star" by the Association for Psychological Science, a designation that recognizes outstanding psychological scientists in the earliest stages of their research career post-PhD "whose innovative work has already advanced the field and signals great potential for their continued contributions.”NEWSLETTER ARCHIVESArchives of the  newsletter are available at http://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/Newsletter.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       APA UPDATE: STUDENT/ECP GRANTS AND CALL FOR COMMENTS(1) The American Psychological Foundation and APA announced $1,000 grants to seed innovation through supporting teaching, education, and intervention projects and programs using psychology to solve social problems such as: how to apply psychology to at-risk, vulnerable populations (e.g., serious mental illness, returning military, those who are incarcerated or economically disadvantaged), preventing violence, understanding the connection between behavior and health (e.g. wellness, diabetes, obesity), and understanding and eliminating stigma and prejudice (e.g. race, gender, sexual orientation, religion, age, disability and socioeconomic status). Applicants must be graduate students or early career researchers (within 10 years of Ph.D.) More information can be obtained at https://www.apa.org/apf/funding/weiss.  Applications are due September 15, 2019. (2) APA seeks member and public comments on the proposed Guidelines for Psychological Practice with Military Service Members, Veterans, and their Families (SMVF). The purpose of these guidelines is to “provide recommendations for psychologists who provide services to SMVF outside of Veterans Health Administration or U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) facilities.” In addition, these guidelines aim to “highlight the main issues that are unique to this particular population that would not necessarily also be of consideration in the civilian population. The successful application of these guidelines involves use of clinical judgment, recognition of one’s own scope of practice, and an understanding of the extent to which military status is part of an individual’s identity or relevant to the individual’s need for psychological care.” Comments can be provided by June 7, 2019 at http://apps.apa.org/commentcentral2/default.aspx?site=40.  For questions related to these updates, please contact your APA Council of Representatives delegates Tom Grisso or Jason Cantone (jasoncantone@gmail.com). If you have any comments about these items, please contact Jason Cantone, at jasoncantone@gmail.com, before August 6. We hope to see you at APA!For the list of nine topics, please click here. EXPERT OPINION: UPCOMING THREE PART SERIESBest practices tell us to choose empirically supported treatment for the individual client. Though we have successfully developed such treatments for many forensic populations, there remains a lack of clearly identified and supported evidenced-based practices for individuals who have committed sexual offenses. In this three-part series, Amanda M. Fanniff, Ph.D., Associate Professor at Palo Alto University, will review current practices and examine whether such treatments actually “work.” This month’s column, Does Treatment for Adults who have Committed Sexual Offenses Work? A Simple Question with a Complicated Answer, focuses on adults who have committed sexual offenses and the next two will look at adolescents who have committed sexual offenses as well as minor attracted persons who want to remain offense-free. We start by asking the question, “How do we measure treatment in this area?”. To read this column, please click here.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          AP-LS BOOK AWARD COMMITTEE INVITES NOMINATIONSThe AP-LS Book Award Committee invites nominations to recognize outstanding scholarship in psychology and law edited books published in 2017 and 2018. APA COMMITTEE ON LEGAL ISSUES (COLI) SEEKS NEW MEMBERSThe APA Committee on Legal Issues (COLI) is one of the most pertinent ways for AP-LS members to become better involved in APA governance and leadership activities. COLI makes recommendations, prepares and issues reports, and educates APA and psychologists about psycho-legal issues and to promote the field of psychology as it interfaces with the law. COLI does not serve as legal counsel to or form an attorney-client relationship with the APA or the Board of Directors. Instead, COLI has a primary responsibility for serving as a “think tank” for the Board of Directors on psycho-legal issues. Nominations are sought for one JD/PhD position and two PhD or PsyD positions. The term of service for all positions is Jan. 1, 2020-Dec. 31, 2022. COLI members must also be APA members. Applications should include (1) a brief statement of no more than 300 words detailing qualifications, and (2) a current curriculum vitae. Nominees' materials will be reviewed by COLI and COLI will send their recommendations to the Board of Directors for review. Applications are due September 27 to COLInominations@apa/org. For more information, please go to: https://www.apa.org/about/offices/ogc/legal-committee-nominations.AP-LS 2020 CONFERENCEThe conference submission site for the AP-LS 2020 conference will be open on September 1, 2019, with submissions due by 11:59 PST on October 4, 2019.                                                                                                                                                                                            EXPERT OPINION: A CALL TO ACTION: TREATMENT FOR ADOLESCENTS WHO HAVE ENGAGED IN ILLEGAL SEXUAL BEHAVIORPart two of a three-part series about evidence-based practices for individuals who have committed sexual offenses. Following August’s focus on adult treatment practices and whether such treatments actually “work,” Amanda M. Fanniff, Ph.D., Associate Professor at Palo Alto University, focuses on adolescents who have committed sexual offenses. As with part one of the series, we start by asking the question, “How do we measure treatment in this area?”To read this column, please click here.LEGAL UPDATE: ASSESSING THREATS OF SELF-DIRECTED VIOLENCE AND DUTIES OF CARE WITHIN HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS: NGUYEN V. MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY (2018)Whereas threat assessment professionals in the United States and Canada may well be aware of case law, other legal standards, and their professional responsibilities regarding assessing and managing risk of violence toward others, fewer may be as familiar with sources of authority regarding self-directed violence threat assessment. It may be reassuring to know that our professional responsibilities related to assessing and managing other- and self-directed violence are somewhat analogous, and the courts have historically, as well as more recently, underscored this view.To read more about this, please click here.CAREER CORNERThe Career Corner is intended to highlight the individuals who work at the intersection of law and psychology, where they come from, how they got there and how their experiences influence their research, teaching, and/or practice. This edition of Career Corner profiles Jennifer L. Groscup, J.D., Ph.D., Professor and Associate Professor of Psychology at Scripps College in Claremont, California.To read this column, please click here.2019 UNDERGRAD PAPER AWARD WINNERSCongratulations to the winners of the undergraduate paper awards!First Place:Elizabeth QuinnThe Blame Game: The Role of Disgust in Hate Crimes against Gay MenNorthwestern UniversityMentor: Allison SkinnerSecond Place:Elizabeth PurserExamining Legal Socialization Processes: Who Influences Adolescents’ Legal Knowledge and Attitudes?University of Texas at El PasoMentor: April ThomasThird Place: Natasha BaileyTactics to Increase Resistance to Varying Amounts of MisinformationUniversity of California, IrvineMentor: J. Additionally, please remember to sign up as a reviewer for proposals!For both submitting proposals and signing up as a reviewer, please visit: http://conferences.ap-ls.org. For more information regarding the conference, please see: http://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/APLS2020.ON THE JOB OR POSTDOC MARKET? AP-LS JOB POSTINGSCheck out AP-LS's Job Postings Page for up-to-date information on available psychology-law positions here.Note that new positions are available.NEWSLETTER ARCHIVESArchives of the  newsletter are available at http://ap-ls.wildapricot.org/Newsletter.AP-LS CONTACTSEmail addresses for all current EC members and Committee Chairs can be found here.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                PRESIDENTIAL COLUMNJennifer GroscupIt was an honor to be elected President of AP-LS, and I am very much looking forward to working with all of you in the upcoming year on our organization. The first thing I want to do is tell you about my Presidential initiative: Embracing Leadership: Developing Skills for Your Career Evolution. This is a leadership training program for our members that will provide participants with the skills and the opportunities to become leaders within our Division and beyond. Based on surveys of our membership and on the surveys done on specific subgroups within our membership (ECPs, Student Section, etc.), there appears to be a high level of interest in leadership development. Many members have expressed the desire to be involved in leadership, but they feel it is difficult to “break into” leadership in the Division. This perception is one of many barriers to leadership for our members, and this feeling is not limited to leadership within the Division.To read the rest of this column, please click here. DIVISION 41 CALL FOR REVIEWERS: APA 128th 2020 ANNUAL CONVENTIONWe are looking for reviewers to review submitted programming proposals for the 128th Annual Convention of the American Psychological Association to be held Aug 6 – 9, 2020 in Washington, DC.Proposals will be in the following formats: symposia, skill-building sessions, discussions, data blitzes, and posters.Student reviewers are welcome!For more information, please click here.The deadline to sign up to be a reviewer is December 2, 2019.CALL FOR APPLICATIONS: EMBRACING LEADERSHIP: DEVELOPING SKILLS FOR YOUR CAREER EVOLUTIONThe American Psychology-Law Society is starting a leadership development program, and we encourage any and all members to apply for this exciting opportunity!Embracing Leadership is designed to provide our members with practical training in leadership and with leadership opportunities within AP-LS. The goals of the program are:1) Provide training for interested members in a variety of leadership skills that could benefit their careers broadly2) Cultivate interest in leadership within the Division3) Provide leadership opportunities within the Division4) Prepare our members to take on leadership challengesFor more information, please click here.Applications are due November 15, 2019.APA COMMITTEE ON LEGAL ISSUES (COLI) SEEKS NEW MEMBERSThe APA Committee on Legal Issues (COLI) is one of the most pertinent ways for AP-LS members to become better involved in APA governance and leadership activities. COLI makes recommendations, prepares and issues reports, and educates APA and psychologists about psycho-legal issues and to promote the field of psychology as it interfaces with the law. COLI does not serve as legal counsel to or form an attorney-client relationship with the APA or the Board of Directors. Instead, COLI has a primary responsibility for serving as a “think tank” for the Board of Directors on psycho-legal issues. Nominations are sought for one JD/PhD position and two PhD or PsyD positions. The term of service for all positions is Jan. 1, 2020-Dec. 31, 2022. COLI members must also be APA members. Applications should include (1) a brief statement of no more than 300 words detailing qualifications, and (2) a current curriculum vitae. Nominees' materials will be reviewed by COLI and COLI will send their recommendations to the Board of Directors for review.For more information, please click here.Applications are due October 8, 2019 to COLInominations@apa.org.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       AAFP DISSERTATION GRAND AWARDSThe American Academy of Forensic Psychology (AAFP) is pleased to announce the following individuals have been awarded Dissertation Grant Awards for 2019. The application process was competitive and the following award recipients were especially impressive. Keisha April, Drexel University, $1,500.00.Dissertation Title:  Let’s “Talk” About the Police: The Role of Race and Intergenerational Transmission of Police Legitimacy Attitudes in the Legal Socialization of YouthEmilie Picard, Fordham University: $1,494.00.Dissertation Title:  Neuropsychological Impairment among Men with Pedophilic Disorder Charged with Possession of Child PornographyLauren Meaux, University of Alabama, $1,050.00.Dissertation Title:  Right Wing Authoritarianism and Psycholegal Opinions in MSO EvaluationsAlexis Humenik, Baylor University, $955.00.Dissertation Title:  The Role of Executive Dysfunction and Substance Use In Intimate Partner Violent OffendersCongratulations to each of these recipients as they stood out in a competitive applicant field. We are confident that they will make substantial contributions to the field of forensic psychology.CALL FOR SUBMISSIONS: APA 2020Ready to present your exciting and interesting work in the area of psychology and the law? Submit programming for the 128th Annual Convention of the American Psychological Association to be held Aug 6 – 9, 2020 in Washington, DC! The American Psychology – Law Society (APA Division 41) invites presentations from any area that involves the intersection of psychology and the law (e.g., practice, teaching, research, policy, law, community outreach).For more information about this, please click here.Proposals must be submitted by December 2, 2019 (5pm EST).CALL FOR COLLABORATIVE PROPOSALS: APA 2020Hello from your 2020 APA Division 41 Co-chairs!We would like to inform you about the unique opportunities presented by Collaborative Programs at APA. APA defines a Collaborative Program as “a cohesive session that showcases multiple perspectives and involves more than one core area of psychology, i.e., science, practice, education, public interest.” These are separate submissions from the usual call for symposia within Division 41, and they are also due earlier (October 11, 2019).For more information, please click here.BETH ROM RYMER SCHOLARSHIPSUp to nine $5,000 scholarships to support training in psychopharmacology programs.  The Beth N. Rom-Rymer Scholarships provide support to both graduate students and practicing, licensed psychologists to complete their training in psychopharmacology programs, which adhere to the APA model curriculum of didactic training in clinical psychopharmacology. The purpose of the scholarships is to encourage talented psychologists, with recognized leadership skills, and with demonstrated passion for growing the field, to become prescribing psychologists, engaged in providing the highest caliber, comprehensive, integrated care to the most at-risk members of the community. Preference will be given to those applicants who are committed to working with the underserved. Approximately half of the scholarships are intended for predoctoral graduate students and approximately half for practicing licensed psychologists at all career levels.  For more information, please click here.The deadline for applications is February 1, 2020.MISCARRIAGES OF JUSTICE, TENTH ANNUAL ISSUE 2019-2020Miscarriages of Justice is a special interdisciplinary issue of Albany Law School’s Albany Law Review, published in collaboration with the University at Albany’s School of Criminal Justice. This annual issue is composed of articles that integrate legal scholarship with social science and/or policy perspectives, and it focuses on problems within or related to the criminal justice system. The tenth annual issue anticipates publication in Spring of 2020. The theme for the 2019–2020 issue is: “Justice Delayed is Justice Denied: A Look at the Influence of Exonerations on Post-Conviction Proceedings in our Legal System and Beyond”.For more information, please click here.Submissions are due October 31, 2019. COUNCIL OF REPRESENTATIVES MEETING UPDATE The APA Council of Representatives met in D.C. February 14-17, 2019. APLS/Division 41 is represented by Jason Cantone and Tom Grisso. At the meeting, Jason Cantone was re-appointed to the Council Diversity Working Group, and elected Member-at-Large for the Public Interest Caucus. Among items on the agenda, Council approved the:· Resolution on Campus Sexual Assault,· Clinical Practice Guideline for the Treatment of Depression Across Three Age Cohorts,· Resolution on Physical Discipline of Children by Parents, after some concerns were expressed about whether the resolution’s claim that science supports that spanking leads to negative outcomes has actually been shown, and concern that the resolution would result in disparities for certain racial, ethnic or cultural communities more likely to use spanking,· 2019 Children and Adolescent Mental and Behavioral Health Resolution (rescinding the now out-of-date 2004 resolution on the same topic),· Revised Model Education and Training Program in Psychopharmacology for Prescriptive Authority,· Creation of a new APA journal, Technology, Mind, and Behavior, and· Proposed change to rules on how Divisions can issue public statements on matters consistent with APA policy, and the information required in APA elections.Last year, Council passed a “transparency” rule to provide for representatives’ individual votes to be made available on the APA website, if 2/3 of Council voted to do so at the beginning of each meeting. Although both APLS representatives voted in support, only 58% of Council supported the motion and it did not pass. Following passionate discussion on the Council members’ LISTSERV, there was an information session regarding the ethical, moral, and legal issues surrounding APA accrediting graduate psychology programs at schools that discriminate against minority (generally, on the basis of sexual orientation) populations. A New Business Item on this issue was proposed for discussion at future meetings.Council also heard from task forces on (1) the new APA strategic plan, which seeks to create a more unifying framework within APA to more readily advocate for psychology, and (2) master’s program accreditation, which will next work on articulating competencies and accreditation standards for masters-level health services professionals, which will still need to be developed and approved.For more on these issues, please contact APLS Council Rep Jason Cantone at jasoncantone@gmail.com. AP-LS CONTACTSEmail addresses for all current EC members and Committee Chairs can be found here.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               AP-LS COMMITTEE VOLUNTEERSAs has been our tradition the past few years, we will be holding a volunteer drive for AP-LS committees at and immediately following AP-LS this year. All committee member terms officially begin in August at APA and the terms are normally three years. Full committee terms of reference can be viewed at: https://goo.gl/5hq6Or. Please attend the Business Meeting at AP-LS to learn more about the committee opportunities. In addition, you may complete the form here: https://goo.gl/forms/agbK8bF6Hf5DtP9u2.FBI’S HIG: CALL FOR WHITE PAPERSThe FBI's High Value Detainee Interrogation Group (HIG) research mandate is to study and evaluate interview/interrogation practices, serving as the locus for advancing the science and practice of interrogation within the United States Government. The HIG research program commissions basic and applied scientific studies and field validation/effectiveness studies to examine current and new approaches to interrogation to develop and refine an effective, non-coercive, science-based model of interrogation, interviewing, and debriefing that is both legally and ethically sound. We fund/commission these basic and applied research projects through a mechanism called the Broad Agency Announcement (BAA). We are currently soliciting new white papers for potential contract funding with a deadline of March 29, 2019.For more information, please click here and select “Amendment 1” for the current call for papers. TEACHING IN PSYCHOLOGY & LAW: LEARNING FROM A MASTER: LANDMARK CASE LAW WITH ALBERT J. GRUDZINSKAS JR. by Brianne K. Layden, Ph.D., Vera A Klinoff, Ph.D., & Heath J. Hodges, Ph.D., M.L.S.This month, 3 former post-docs remember and reflect on the approach that made Landmark Case Law a pivotal training experience for generations of trainees under the expert teaching of the late Albert J. Grudzinskas Jr.To read this column, please click here. ON THE JOB OR POSTDOC MARKET? AP-LS JOB POSTINGSCheck out AP-LS's Job Postings Page for up-to-date information on available psychology-law positions here.Note that new positions are available.       EARLY CAREER GRANT IN AID AWARDS

We are pleased to announce the winners of the 2019 AP-LS Grants in Aid for Early Career Professionals. The winners (in alphabetical order) are:

Dr. Fabiana Alceste

“'It’s Not Your Fault You’re a Criminal': Causal Attributions in Interrogation Tactics”

Congratulations to the winners!



SEEKING VOLUNTEERS FOR OUTREACH EFFORTS IN NEW ORLEANS

As some of you may remember, we did outreach efforts in Memphis and Portland at our 2018 and 2019 conferences. This year, we plan to do similar outreach efforts in New Orleans middle and high schools. Therefore, we’re asking you to fill out a very simple form online to indicate your interest. We will use those responses to create our list of potential volunteers and then we will be in touch in February to work out the details. Please follow this link by Wednesday, January 1, 2020.

As we did in years past, we will be going into local schools on Thursday morning (March 5th) before AP-LS officially begins and talking with students about law-psychology generally and the specific research interests of our members. We got overwhelmingly positive feedback from the local students and AP-LS members from our previous experiences so we’re looking forward to another great experience this year.

The AP-LS Book Award Committee invites nominations to recognize outstanding scholarship in psychology and law edited books published in 2017 and 2018. The deadline for nominations has been extended to December 6, 2019.  Nominations (including self-nominations) and e-versions of the book should be sent to the Chair of the Committee:  Marie Comiskey, BA LLB LLM SJD, Marie.Comiskey@utoronto.ca.

The American Psychology-Law Society confers Dissertation Awards for scientific research and scholarship relevant to the promotion of the interdisciplinary study of psychology and law. Students who complete dissertations involving basic or applied research in psychology and law in 2019 are encouraged to apply for these awards. First, second, and third-place awards will be conferred; winners will be invited to present their research at the annual AP-LS conference and receive a cash award. Submissions are due by 12/31/19.

For application details please click here, or, for more information, please contact Jacqueline Evans, the chair of the Dissertation Awards Committee, at jacevans@fiu.edu.

To apply for one of these grants (which cover the workshop registration fee), please complete the application here by Friday, January 10, 2020. ELECTIONS FOR 2019-2020; NOMINATIONS DUE TODAYAs described in an email you should have received on January 13, 2019, we have an election upcoming in mid-April that will be held to fill the Division 41 positions of President-elect, Council Representative, and Member-at-Large. For more information about these positions, please see: http://www.apadivisions.org/division-41/leadership/executive-committee/index.aspx.  We are seeking nominations, including self-nominations, for these three positions. You must be a current AP-LS member to run for these positions, and you must also be an APA member to run for Council Representative.  If you’re interested in being considered for the election slate, please send the following materials to Eve Brank (ebrank2@unl.edu), Chair of the AP-LS Nominations and Awards Committee:             CV                  Letter(s) in support of the nominee                  Statement of interest (for self-nominations)      If you are nominating someone for the election slate, please ensure they are willing to run if they are selected to be on the ballot. All nominations are due by Friday, February 1, 2019. Sometimes staying on top of all the news, research and legal updates relevant to the field can be a daunting task. AP-LS RETAINS ITS APA SEATS; GRAD STUDENT VOTING MEASURE FAILS

Thank you to everyone who voted in the APA Apportionment Ballot this fall. The results determine the composition of APA's Council of Representatives. With the voting now closed, AP-LS retained its two seats for 2021. Two divisions lost a seat (Society for the Psychology of Women; Trauma Psychology) and two divisions gained a seat (Society of Counseling Psychology; Society for the Psychology of Religion and Spirituality). The percentage of votes AP-LS received slightly increased compared to last year, but AP-LS remains very low in the voting tallies. Make sure to vote each year to keep AP-LS' voice heard in APA! In 2020, the AP-LS Council representatives are Jason Cantone and Margaret Bull Kovera. 

The bylaws amendment seeking to expand APA voting privileges for graduate students failed by a very narrow margin. Bylaws amendments must be approved by two-thirds (66.67%) of APA voting members, but only 65.98% voted to approve this amendment. The measure passed Council in August 2019 with 73% of Council Representatives voting yes.

Editor-in-Chief

I am excited to announce that Dr. Jennifer Cox has joined the Editorial Team of Law and Human Behavior. She and Dr. Dave DeMatteo will work with reviewers to make publication decisions for clinical submissions to the journal.

Dr. Cox received her doctorate in clinical psychology from Texas A&M University in 2014. She is currently an Associate Professor who specializes in clinical psychology-law at The University of Alabama. She has served on LHB Editorial Board since 2015 and currently serves on the editorial board of three journals and the AP-LS Committees for Research and Dissertation Awards. Her research interests include the impact of gender and race biases on legal decision making, forensic mental health assessment, psychopathy, and the interaction of psychology and public policy.

Dr. Cox replaces Dr. Amanda Zelechoski, who recently stepped down as Associate Editor to tend to family medical issues and to focus on several new projects. The journal not only benefitted from Dr. Zelechoski’s expertise as AE—she was also the driving force behind the journal’s new Reviewer Mentee Program. LEGAL UPDATE: RESOLUTION OR RESIGNATION: THE ROLE OF FORENSIC MENTAL HEALTH PROFESSIONALS AMIDST THE COMPETENCY SERVICES CRISIS

Competency-related cases often occur in under-resourced, over-taxed systems of evaluation and care, despite the efforts of dedicated personnel found working in those systems. Forensic psychologists may have difficulty adhering to overarching ethical principles if our work occurs unabated in the midst of the inhumane conditions that often surround competency-related services.       NORMAN J. FINKELI regret to inform the Division that one of our distinguished members, Norman J. Finkel passed away last month on December 2, 2019. Norm Finkel spent most of his career in the Psychology Department at Georgetown University. He was on the faculty for thirty-seven years, beginning in 1970. He received his bachelor’s degree in Psychology from N.Y.U., where he studied with Phil Zimbardo, and his Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology from Rochester University. At Georgetown, he taught Abnormal Psychology and Psychology and Law, as well as advanced seminars in Theories of Therapy, and Madness, Genius, and Creativity. In 2005, he received the College Dean’s Award for Excellence in Undergraduate Teaching, reflecting his deep devotion to undergraduate students whom he taught with great dedication, flair, and with a particular focus on deepening students’ thinking and critical capacities. He was a leader in the field of psychology and law. During his career, he wrote many influential books in the field including Therapy and Ethics: The Courtship of Law and Psychology (1980), Mental Illness and Health (1982), Insanity on Trial (1988), Commonsense Justice: Jurors’ Notions of the Law (1995), Not Fair! The Typology of Commonsense Unfairness (2001), The Psychology of Rights and Duties: Empirical Contributions and Normative Commentaries (2005), and Emotions and Culpability: How the Law Is at Odds with Psychology, Jurors, and Itself (2006). He is survived by his daughter Jennifer, his sister Debbie, and countless friends and family, including his good friend Steve Sabat, Emeritus at Georgetown, who provided me with much of the information above from his own tribute to Norm for the department.

This is a great personal loss for me, as well as a loss for our field. I first met Norm as a student in his Theories of Therapy class at Georgetown. He was an exceptional teacher – funny, quirky, and engaging. There always was an element of theater in his teaching. If I’m being honest, I was an unexceptional student in that class. That was not our moment. In the fall of my senior year, I was still at a bit of a loss for what area of psychology interested me most. I knew I wanted to pursue something in the area of criminal psychology, but I wasn’t sure what or how. That’s when I took his Psychology and Law class, and it changed my life. Not only did it inspire me intellectually to pursue work in this field, but it also gave me a roadmap for how to teach more generally. In that class, there were so many “Jennifer”s (as is the curse of many people my age), that he gave us all nicknames. Mine was “44” because my middle name is Leigh, and Lee Grosscup (no relation to my knowledge) was an NFL Football player who I guess played with that number. At the very bottom of his syllabus for the class he encouraged anyone interested in doing research to contact him. I had never seen that before as a student. At the time, I had no idea what that really meant but I thought why not? I didn’t know going in what a prolific researcher he was or how important that experience would be for me. I worked with him my whole senior year, learning how to design studies, collect data, and most importantly, how to “think big” about the impact of psychology on the legal system.

I continued to work with him for three years after graduation until I went to graduate and law school. He was a constant guiding force for me, providing me with opportunities, advice, and new knowledge. I know I would not be where I am today, in this field and in a career that I love, without his mentoring. Now, as a professor, I try to emulate his enthusiasm for learning and his openness and dedication to undergraduate research and education. I put a similar blurb at the bottom of the syllabus in every class I teach, inviting students to contact me if they are interested in research. I tell them this story. I have met and mentored some of the most amazing people because of this – because of him. I’m sure many of you have a “Norm” in your lives that sparked your interest in psychology and law. Take a minute to let them know, and never underestimate your own ability to light that spark for someone else.

In fond remembrance,

Jen Groscup (44)

If you would like to make a donation to honor his memory, the family has suggested the ACLU and the Holocaust Memorial in Washington DC as organizations with missions close to his heart.

Lora M. Levett, PhD

Associate Editor

llevett@ufl.edu

Announcing the 2020 Law and Human Behavior Reviewer Mentoring Program!

Have you always wondered how people get to be reviewers for prestigious journals? Are you interested in becoming a reviewer for LHB (the official journal of AP-LS), but don’t know what that means or how to get training and experience with providing strong reviews? Do you have limited or no access to a mentor that can provide you with this type of experience? If so, now’s your chance to develop your reviewer skills!

The LHB editorial team is continuing their Reviewer Mentoring Program in 2020 to provide current graduate students and ECPs (within 10 years of last terminal degree) with training and mentoring specifically in conducting strong peer reviews. If you will be attending the AP-LS conference in March 2020 and do not have access to this type of mentoring in your current graduate program, we invite you to apply for the program.

We will be selecting a small pilot group of Reviewers to participate in a training workshop at the 2020 AP-LS conference and then matching those participants with Reviewer Mentors. Mentees will then be assigned several manuscripts to review throughout 2020, under the supervision and guidance of their Reviewer Mentor.

If you would like to be considered for this program, please complete the application at the following link by February 5 (https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/LHBReviewing).

Division 41 in D.C. 

August 6-9

Division 41 has developed an exciting program based on the numerous high-quality submissions received. Highlights include the discussion Want more forensic psychologists of color? Try listening, as well as the symposia Considerations for forensic evaluations with adults diagnosed with Intellectual Disabilities and Mass Shootings in America: A multi-method study of the past 50 years. Of note, APA at large is "re-envisioning" the Convention, which has been associated with a decrease in Division-specific programming hours. We received many more submissions than our allotted hours (15). This made for a very competitive process. Thank you to all reviewers who volunteered their time and expertise. See you in D.C.! 



5K FUN RUN!

Don't forget to sign up for the Annual Student Committee 5k Fun Run before February 15, 2020! 

The Annual 5K will be Friday, March 6, 2020 at 7:00 AM. Registration is $25.00 and includes a t-shirt as well as snacks after the race. All proceeds go to support the Student Committee activities. Sign up for the Fun Run here.

This year, we're going digital! When you register, you must also complete this waiver and upload it with your registration.
